I do not know.  Our whole group who was together was called up.  Some of the people did not go.
Now the instructions, let's call it at the last Order Meeting which you attended, the instructions which were given there, how broad were they and what did they entail?
It was with regards to this call up instruction to the Trim Park in Ventersdorp.
Was it just a call up instruction or did you discuss broader strategies?
No, it's how we'd move up there and how we'd go there, what we'd do with our house, our cars and the fact that we should take caravans with, tents, it was a very broad discussion that evening.
Yes but was any mention made of operations?
Yes we were told that we were going to move into certain operations.
But was there any indication of what the nature of these operations would be?
We, it was discussed the whole Volkstaat idea and that there would be a security group formed and we would be involved in that and that we would also have to do certain operations.
But except for the Volkstaat idea and that you would carry it together, were other further operations discussed at the Order Meeting.  Were there any other discussion with regards to operations?
I think at that stage, I cannot remember exactly what the agenda was, Commandant Fourie was there but it's very possible that it was discussed.
I do not expect of you to remember all the detail after such a long time Mr Le Roux, I would just like to know, to put it simply, was there talk about bomb explosions etc?
You mentioned that you differed from Barnard with regards to the choice of targets.  Can you indicate to us what was the basis of these differences were, with regards to what aspects did you differ?
I would have chosen a power station or something similar as a target.
Did Barnard tell you why he did not want that to be the case?
No he did not say, he only said that he had an instruction to bomb the targets as he indicated.
And now the meeting you attended of General Constand Viljoen, which date was that, how long before these incidents?
So it's round about two months before the incidents?

And then just a last question, maybe you did deal with it, maybe I'm asking you again but it would seem as if the leadership of the AWB is very hesitant to come to the front.  You were very unsure about who would come and testify for you here.  Did you discuss this amongst yourselves why this is the case?
Chairperson I wanted the leader here, I also asked him to be here but he did not come Chairperson.

I used the word leadership or leader's corp.  Except for Terreblanche, what about Prinsloo.  It would seem as if the Generals in general are very hesitant to come to this commission.  Did you discuss this with your co-applicants?
Yes Chairperson, the basic idea is that the revolution was lost in 1994 and now they cannot suddenly come forward with new different things, they wouldn't gain anything from that.
Yes but it could help you Mr Le Roux, that's problematic for me.
You did make mention of the fact that you wrote a letter to Mr Terreblanche?

The little organisation which we founded and gave a name to amongst ourselves, we addressed three letters to him.  It was before the cut off point of the amnesty.  One was for the ABW's leader, the one was to General Constand Viljoen and the other one to the AWB leader and there was asked them to please submit their amnesty applications so that they can testify for us in order to give us assistance because we knew that they were part of the whole process.
The only one who reacted was General Constand Viljoen.  He also wrote me a letter and I have the letter here today Chairperson.
Sorry just let me repeat the question.  What was his response?

He ensured us that he would mention our names in his amnesty application and the amnesty applications would be submitted and that the papers would make it public what his plans were at that stage and that we could use that.  He also presented it as such Chairperson.
Was there a follow up.  Did Constand Viljoen mention your group in any of his applications?
That which I picked up on our radio stations etc, he did mention our names.
And did you try and make contact with General Prinsloo?
In which way did you make contact with him?
A while ago he came to visit us in Leeukop Prison.
Did you tell him that he must come and help as your superiors?
He said that they will do everything within their power, we shouldn't be worried.
Did you talk to him about the question of evidence?
I wanted him to be here Chairperson.
Did you ask him General you mustn't do this behind people's backs, you must come here and give evidence?
Yes I stressed that in my letters and every time I emphasised the fact that he was involved, he was part of the plan, please come and appear here.
And this is my last question and it is about General Prinsloo, did you emphasise to Prinsloo that you wanted him to testify for you?
I asked them to come and give evidence Chairperson.
Let us stay with General Prinsloo.
And what was his answer to that?

He said that we shouldn't be worried.  I cannot remember his exact words, but it came down to the fact that we shouldn't be worried because they will appear for us.  The leader of the AWB also promised that he would be here yesterday Chairperson and he did not appear.
Thank you Chair.  If you just look at page 57 of Volume 1, paragraph 12?

My understanding of that and please correct me if I am wrong, is essentially that those members of the AWB who participated in this resistance would become part of this Boere Afrikaner Volkstaat Police?

Now my question is, is that what motivated you to go up to Ventersdorp (1) and (2) is that what motivated you further to make sure that everybody knew you were participating in something so that you could then become part of this Boere Afrikaner Volkstaat Police?
This was part of my motivation and I realised that we've got work to do there and that we could make an existence out of that, so it was part of the motivation Chairperson.

And you don't think this amounts to any kind of personal benefit.  You know you were really looking at what you could get out of this thing, you personally, more than being married to the idea of your Volkstaat?
No in my business I made much more money than I would ever have received there so I wouldn't have gained any benefit from that Chairperson.
Yes but you see you didn't sell that business, you simply shut it down and you kept that on the back burners so to say?
Why was that if you were really uprooting yourself and your family to go and fight for your cause and live in an area that would be part of who you were?
I did not know what the future held during that time.  We took our guesses and we acted according to them.

Now a related question comes back to the issue of leaving home and as I understand your evidence, you were going there to form part of this general resistance that you had been called up to come and become part of?

And again, as I understand your evidence, at the stage that you left your home, there was nothing about stopping the elections as such, going up to stop the elections, you were there so that you could gather and ensure that you had a piece of ground that you would call your Volkstaat where you would live in peace as a Volk?

So really the whole thing about disruption of the elections or stopping the elections as you put it, what essentially amounted to acts of terror, terrorist acts between the 24th and 27th is something you essentially got from Barnard, it's not something you came up with when you came up from home?

No Chairperson the bombs themselves, I knew nothing of them before the time.  I was willing to plant bombs if I had to do it but I didn't even know where.  I didn't know anything about the bombs up until the 23rd.

What I'm trying to understand, and if you could help me with this, is where the terrorist actions, if one might call them, the acts of terror 24th to the 27th and the ideal of the AWB to create a Volkstaat for it's people, how you marry the two - can I just finish because it's something I still don't understand.  These acts of terror, as I understand it were not part of the general plan of the AWB and correct me if I am wrong, the AWB said essentially, we will not be ruled by a Black government and certainly not by an ANC/SACP government, the day that happens there is going to be a general uprising of all our people because we will not be ruled by these people, we believe in self determination.

Now on the 24th there had been no ANC government, it was left to chance essentially.  Yet that is where your first act of terror, where your involvement comes in, that's where your first act of terror starts.  The AWB objective had not been created, or rather the environment for that uprising had not been created yet, you didn't know who was going to take over, the NP could have won that election?

Chairperson I was under the impression that the AWB did have complete plans to negotiate for a Volkstaat, I thought that and that was my opinion at that stage.  I was part of the planning, I didn't know about the complete planning but on my level I knew that we were called up and that were going to take part in certain operations.  I did not know what was the broader planning of the Staff Generals or of General Constand Viljoen or the CP, I did not know anything about that, but I knew they had plans, they were busy with it and that they wanted to establish a Volkstaat in that area.

I can understand that, you see I group underneath what I would call your political motivation, it was there, you were politically motivated but it' the objective that you as a member were working towards, were trying to achieve and it's those dates the 24th to the 27th, particularly the 24th.  Where does the motivation and the, where do they conflate, where do they meet each other, you as a person as participating in this.

I saw it like this:  The Ystergarde was a specialist unit of the AWB and they would have, or the operations that needed more experience, they would then execute them.  They would not take part in the normal operations which for example the Wen Kommando would take part in so that is where I said or thought if they wanted bombs to be planted, this is probably part of the process of the broader plan of the AWB.

And you would therefore say you weren't simply acting as a group of spoilers, spoiling a process you know you essentially couldn't change, you know which is different to being organised as AWB members preferring a particular objective, you know the spoiler image and the military organised AWB image?
We were highly motivated political ideals.

The last aspect, which is slightly different is, you know when I look at the documents we have before us and I'm looking at everything, not just your application, the targets that Bree Street area essentially, by 1994 a whole group of, many Black people were living in that Bree Street, Park Station, Hillbrow area essentially.  You will agree with that?
Yes I am aware of that Chairperson.
Right.  Germiston, the taxi rank, largely Black people again who milled about that area be it on a Sunday or a Tuesday?

Then I look at some of these Randfontein attacks, I know you weren't involved in those, Black areas.  Now I understood you to say that you weren't part of, or you didn't subscribe to apartheid as such, you subscribed to self determination, you try and separate the two.  Why, if I look at these documents before us and the applications before us, why these Black areas, Black targets, when I look at all of them here.  You know the only ones that I would say was not a Black area per se was the then Jan Smuts Airport and you go and take great care to go an put your bomb in an underground parking area.  You know with all the others you make sure that it's in a very obvious area where there will be maximum damage, but with the Black areas you choose, it's specific to those areas and yet you are not, it's not a racial war you say you're fighting.  You know your focus is on self determination in line with you and documents and all kinds of other things.
That is not my view of the targets, but I would say the basic idea was that most of the Black people do belong to the ANC and that could have been the motivation behind this.
Do I understand you correctly then if you say that the whole incident of incidents were targeted at the ANC?
No, no Mr Chairperson.  We had two enemies, that was the National Party government and the ANC who we knew would come into power.
So it was directed at the ANC.

Yes you see yesterday I understood you to say really it's the NP government that was selling you out, that that really was your major target, NP government that was selling you out and yes coincidentally, at this stage between the 24th and the 27th, those were the people you were trying to deal with and you would deal with the ANC government should it take power.  Now on the 24th why go for Black area, you see this is what I keep grappling with ...(intervention)

That was not a specifically Black are Mr Chairperson, the Bree Street area.  There could have been more Black people but like I explained earlier on the reason for the bomb was basically go to Johannesburg, plant a bomb and come out as soon as possible and that was the principle.
Yes, maybe I should leave it at that.  Thank you Mr Le Roux.
Mr Le Roux when you began with your evidence you said that you come from a very conservative family, what do you mean by that?

Conservative in lifestyle and my father was also a government man.  I was brought up and we were proud to serve in the Defence Force.  We went to airforce shows etc.  We supported the country, we were patriotic and regarding that conservative.
Now tell me, when you were informed that certain bombs must be planted at certain places or areas, did you question this, you yourself?
I did discuss it, especially with Barnard.
I'm asking you if you questioned it?
No not as such Mr Chairperson, I saw it as an order that we must execute and I saw myself as part of the much larger plan.
Did you know what that larger plan was?
How can you then see yourself as part of a larger plan if you don't know what the plan was?
From the stage we regularly got the principles of what it was about and that there would be a revolution.
Especially, did you discuss the political results of these events and did you question them?
Yes we did discuss it amongst ourselves.  I did talk a lot about politics.
No, I'm talking about the bomb plantings.  There were certain results and you could foresee what would happen?
Yes that is correct but it was so quick that on the 23rd I was in the whole process and the next day the bomb exploded.
But on the way there must have been enough time to reflect?
I was driving alone, I did think about it.
It's probably better that you drove alone, you had time to reflect?
Mr Chairperson at that stage I believed in what I was doing.
One of the reasons why these bombs were planted was to inform the world or whoever about the policy of the AWB and what they are looking for.  Is that not true?
Mr Chairperson it was not just the policy of the AWB, here were various political parties involved and I saw it in a broader sense.
I did not understand it as such, but I hear what you are saying.  Who would have been responsible for the consequences of the bombings?
I believed that the AWB would have taken responsibility.
Is that not one of the reasons why you contributed because the AWB wanted to show the world what their policy was?
Yes that is the expression of the policy.
The first bomb was planted on the 23rd in Bree Street?
At approximately ten minutes to ten in the morning.
The second bomb was I think around eight or nine o'clock.
No it was the next day, the Monday.
That was approximately 24 hours between the two bombings?
By six o'clock that morning no one had taken responsibility for the bombing in Bree Street.  Is that not correct?

Did you not then at that stage think one of the most important reasons I'm taking part in this is to show the world what we want and here there's a bomb where people were killed and no one comes forward to say we take responsibility and give a reason.  What was your position then, did you not think that the plan is not working very well?
Mr Chairperson as far as I can remember some of the newspapers did speculate that it was the right wing unrest that was taking place.

Well that was not your plan before the first bomb planting.  Before then you expected, I don't not know why, but you expected that someone in the AWB would stand up and say we planted the bomb and these are the reasons?
Yes that is correct, I hoped for it and I criticised it afterwards.
But by six o'clock the following morning no one had come forward to claim responsibility?
At that stage did you not then, did you know that you were going to plant a bomb in Germiston?
Did you not then at that stage think I wonder if my participation in this is right because it doesn't seem as if anyone is going to stand up and tell the world why the bomb was planted?
Mr Chairperson I thought that it was part of the process, I did not know what the main planning part was.  I hoped that they would take responsibility and present their claims and ...(intervention)
Why did you think that somebody would stand up and tell the world.  Why is the world so important?
Any state that is created must be accepted by the countries and the world at large.
Now you say there was speculation that the bombs were planted by the right wing?
It was made or created by someone who by coincidence has a white skin.  Is that no so?
No I wouldn't say that Mr Chairperson.
Well is there such a thing as a Black Afrikaner?
Some people call it that.  An Afrikaner Boer is a White person, it's about ethnicity.
Now the planning of the bomb in Germiston, why would it mainly occur where mostly, if not all, Black people were present, is it not so?
Did you not think that after the explosion of that bomb, there would be Black and White conflict or did you know about it?
That is what we suspected Chairperson.
Is that not what you wanted?
No I did not want it to take place, I was part of a revolution.
Was that not important for you to prevent it?
No Mr Chairperson, like I'm saying, if I chose a target I would have chosen a different target.
But that is why I asked, when the idea that the bombs must be planted, did you not question it?
I did question it and the result of it, I did think about it yes.
And for yourself, was it not important to prevent Black and White conflict in South Africa?

Mr Chairperson the biggest enemy we had at that stage was the Whites, it was not the Blacks as such.
It does not mean that if we are Afrikaner Boere, everybody agrees with our principles.  There are other people with different ideas.
But still, the results would have been far more serious this country if there had been Black and White conflict at that stage?

We expected that the ANC would also act during that period.  It was put to us from the stages and from meetings that we had to prepare ourselves for that so it was assumed that there would be Black and White conflict.
I am talking about your own personal view.  How did you see things.  Here is possible large scale conflict between Black and White, am I doing the right thing?
I did expect it in any case, the conflict that you are now talking about.
Did you not think that it was wrong?
No the conflict as a result of the bomb plantings?
I'm not a person who likes conflict, I would rather like to live in my own freedom and in dignity.
But that's my point, you don't need a professor to realise that there would be Black and White conflict after the bombing of that specific area.  Is that not so?
Mr Le Roux can you just tell us how you imagined this conflict, in your own mind?

It varies from the Order Groups, we were shown a document where it was indicated that some of the right wing members had been identified to be killed by the security forces of the time in order to neutralise us and I took this seriously and thought that they would do it.  I knew that if, and that is the same as the newspaper article of General Constand Viljoen, he expected it as well and just like him, I also expected that there would be chaos in the country and out of that, we would have been able to get the Volkstaat.
Do I understand you correctly to say that you thought that Black and White would indiscriminately start killing one another and that would have been the right climate from which to get the Volkstaat?
Yes I think so Chairperson.  We wanted to enforce the Volkstaat in order to show the world and that's why we planted the bomb Chairperson, but I didn't see a Black/White conflict as such.

But I think that is what the Chairperson asked you and I am very confused now.  The Chairperson asked you if you foresaw that there was going to be Black/White conflict and with that I accepted general conflict.  Did you foresee a general Black/White conflict?
I thought it could take place Chairperson.
And I also followed it up by saying whether you thought that Black and White people would indiscriminately now start killing each other?
No that wouldn't have happened Chairperson.
How did you see it, how was it going to happen according to you.  Were the political groups going to attack each other?

Yes the basic political groups, in other words the MK, the ANC, fighters would be involved in certain operations and amongst the AWBs and the right-wingers certain people would be killed among them, that type of thing Chairperson.
Now you are saying that at one stage you did question these activities.  Did you discuss that with Barnard?
Sorry Chairperson I didn't hear well?
This bomb planting strategy, you questioned it and also discussed it with Barnard?
And you felt that you could discuss it with him and question it?
So it wasn't a question that you simply followed instructions?
No Chairperson, but he told me listen these bombs have to be placed there and the instructions come from the Staff Generals.
You had the feeling that he could have chosen somebody else to do that work if you did not agree to do it?
So once again it was not a question of you going through this because of the instruction you received, you did it yourself?
No I did it under instruction Chairperson.
But you could have pulled out from it and he would have found somebody else?
So you wanted to be part of this?
Yes I wanted to be part of obtaining of a Volkstaat.
But did you want to be part of the bombing?
You could have decided not to do it?
So why did you go ahead with it?
I saw myself as part of this team which was fighting for certain principles and it was because of that I said okay let's do that.
You discussed the whole thing with Barnard I assume also the consequences and you knew why the bombs had to be planted?
It seems to me that this whole plan or plans would have necessarily entailed the death of people?
I don't know Chairperson.  I said that that will be the effect, and that's the way we discussed it Chairperson.
But that's the point, you discussed it with Barnard and you can't tell me why the taking of lives was necessarily part of the plan?
Chairperson in order to plant a bomb and you blow away a lot of bricks, it's not going to draw the attention of anybody, but if a few people died, that's newsworthy.
So the taking of lives was deliberate?
Yes it was Chairperson.  That was my instruction Chairperson.

Let's talk about the planting of the bomb in Bree Street, I don't know what it's called in Afrikaans.  We all know now and a great part of the community before April 1994 knew that the personnel of State or government buildings came from a certain part of the community, they were White people.  Is that not so?

Is that not maybe the reason why government were not the targets because the possibility existed that White people could have been killed or that Sunday evening they wouldn't have a job on the Monday?
No Chairperson, the instruction was that we place the bomb there.  If it was planted in front of a post office then it would have depended on the General staff.
Did you imagine or suggest rather that the bomb should be placed before the post office or other government building?
No Chairperson I said why didn't we blow up a power station, that was my suggestion.
What was the reaction to that?
He said no that's not why we are here.  The instruction is to specifically bomb those places as we bombed them.
But you were the person who had to decide about a specific place in Johannesburg because your friends did not know Johannesburg very well?
Chairperson the other people, like I've said, didn't even know where Johannesburg was.
I knew where it was, I knew the basic set up and my instruction was go to Johannesburg and indicate to us a place where we can place this bomb.
Why not at a sports stadium?
You could have chosen, it's in the middle of Johannesburg?
Barnard said with the Bree Street bomb he wanted buildings.
And one of the biggest buildings in Johannesburg is a sport stadium?
Well why not the sports stadium?
As I said, my personal idea was to find the quickest route into Johannesburg and there where you find buildings, that's where you plant the bomb and you leave immediately Chairperson.
Did you think Bree Street was the place that you leave from the quickest?
Is the place I could have disposed of the bomb in the quickest way.  To drive with a bomb is not a nice thing.
I accept what you're saying, I have never driven with a bomb.  Now the time when the first bomb was planted, did you know that Mr Viljoen was now going to take part in the elections?
And therefore he was distanced from the plans of the AWB?
I never got the idea that he was at a distance from us, we all had the impression that he was following, he had other options to follow.  He also still had the military option and ...(intervention)
But he exercised his option right before the election?
Yes but he spoke of this option specifically at the meeting at the show in Pretoria, that he wanted to go and vote.
But that's the point, if he chooses one of the options it excludes the other.
He did not reject the military option Chairperson.
Did he ever say that he was going to exercise both options.  Then it's not an option, it's two strategies, isn't it?
But you keep talking about an option which he chose and the option he chose was to take part in the elections and therefore it excludes the other option then?
Yes, with the two things that he chose, the one was the negotiation with the elections and the other one was the military option.

Now the last aspect I want to deal with, when you were on your way to Ventersdorp did you know or did you have an idea that there's going to be interference or an effort to interfere with the election?
I thought there would be total chaos and disorder with the election.
Which you and others would have caused?
Yes which others as well as myself would have caused.

When you said to your wife look we're closing up the business, we're going to Ventersdorp to stay on a farm and these are the reasons, did you know that one of the things that you were going to be asked to do was to interfere with the upcoming elections?
I suspected that we might be tasked to do that.
That was one of the things that had to be done?
Look we realised that we had to stop the elections Chairperson, we realised this before the time.
No not at all, I did not know the broad plan.
So how did you think you would go about stopping the elections?
I didn't have a plan, I had a suspicion that it would be by planting bombs and throwing the country into disaster and chaos.
And you went to Ventersdorp with the idea that there would be about 100 000 soldiers assisting you and that Mr Viljoen was part of this operation.
But then Viljoen decided to take part in the election.  Did you not think then that that would take most of those soldiers away?
No Chairperson I did not think that.
No Chairperson.  I though that he was still going forward with his military option.

But I don't think that came through very clearly.  Did you understand the instruction to be the inner city of Johannesburg?

Yes but Houghton is a suburb Chairperson.
